awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type I - Florida Atlantic University I-Corps Site for Advancing Entrepreneurship and Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create an NSF I-Corps Site at Florida Atlantic University (FAU) as a component of the FAU Tech Runway (FAUTR), the university's early-stage business incubator/ accelerator. 

Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The I-Corps Site will significantly enhance the existing FAUTR's ability to positively impact the local innovation ecosystem. This project enhances the continuous development of expert entrepreneurs that will ultimately cultivate a strong local innovation ecosystem in one of the most densely populated areas of the country. At FAU, a designated Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), the I-Corps Site program also helps increase the participation of Hispanic entrepreneurs in STEM innovation. The long-term objective of this project is to increase and retain the number of newly formed innovative companies capable of accelerating innovations to the market and attracting investors and industry partners to the region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

The Florida Atlantic University (FAU) I-Corps Site, supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF), has significantly contributed to fostering entrepreneurship and innovation in southeastern Florida. This report summarizes the outcomes and impacts of the project, emphasizing its intellectual merit and broader societal benefits.

Intellectual Merit

The FAU I-Corps Site was established to advance entrepreneurial education and support the commercialization of STEM research. Over the course of the project, FAU trained 194 entrepreneurial teams across 12 cohorts, exceeding its target of 24 teams annually. These teams comprised of students, faculty, and/or community entrepreneurs, demonstrating a diverse pool of innovators.

Major Activities

  1. Entrepreneurial Training: Each cohort underwent rigorous five-week training programs, emphasizing the Lean Startup methodology. Activities included customer discovery interviews, business model validation, workflows and mapping, office hour check-ins, even prototyping and beta testing. Teams also received training in innovation-focused tools such as the Innovation Within software platform. We also hosted a virtual Florida wide cohort in collaboration with USF, UM, and FIU.
  2. Train-the-Trainer Workshops: FAU expanded its pool of qualified instructors and mentors by hosting in house workshops for our mentor cadre.
  3. Integration with University Programs: The I-Corps methodology was incorporated into other FAU programs, such as Tech Runway and the Wave program, enhancing cross-departmental collaboration and the entrepreneurial ecosystem.

Significant Results

  • Several teams validated their product-market fit, with notable successes including Lock It Plates, which secured distribution contracts, and SPods, which filed a patent for a biodegradable hand-sanitizing capsule.
  • Two student participants, Satviki Singh and John Thomerson, were invited to the National Academy of Inventors Summit, showcasing innovations in wound healing and adaptive technologies for disabled pets.
  • The founder of Neptunya, a device that harnesses ocean energy, received an SBIR grant award, further advancing his innovative work.
  • Approximately 15 teams progressed to apply and were eligible for National I-Corps training, with some advancing to SBIR/STTR grant applications.
  • The project facilitated interdisciplinary learning, equipping participants with business and entrepreneurial skills critical for translating research to real-world applications.

Broader Impacts

The FAU I-Corps Site has profoundly impacted southeastern Florida’s entrepreneurial ecosystem, driving societal and economic benefits.

Impact on Society

  1. Diversity and Inclusion: Women and minority-led teams constituted over 50% of participants, reflecting FAU’s commitment to equitable access and inclusion in entrepreneurship.
  2. Economic Development: Teams participating in I-Corps programs contributed to the regional economy by creating startups, winning grants, creating jobs, and attracting investment. The FAU Office of Technology Development reported gross intellectual property revenue of over $140,000 for fiscal year 2024, stemming from 9 patents issued and 6 licenses executed​.
  3. Community Outreach: The program extended its reach beyond Boca Raton, involving participants from other Florida universities such as the University of Florida, Florida State University, Lynn University, Palm Beach State College, and Embry Riddle Aeronautical University. This program also impacted South Florida-based startups such as Carbon Limit and EpiPaws. This collaborative approach strengthened Florida’s broader innovation ecosystem.

Technological Advancements

The program catalyzed technological innovations with societal relevance. For instance:

  • Sharkskin Bandage: A biomimetic invention designed to reduce reinfections, potentially saving healthcare costs and improving patient outcomes.
  • Spods: Providing accessible sanitation solutions for underserved communities, enhancing public health and hygiene.
  • CubeSat Team: Developed a miniature satellite prototype, enabling advancements in space exploration and food sustainability, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration among engineering and science students.
  • EqualWater: A portable solar powered water purification device, that successfully completed the National I-Corps program

Educational Impact

I-Corps training refined the instructional methods of FAU faculty, integrating practical entrepreneurial techniques such as customer discovery into coursework. Undergraduate and graduate students reported enhanced critical thinking and iterative problem-solving skills, with many leveraging these capabilities to compete in national and regional entrepreneurial competitions.

Human Resource Impact

The I-Corps program fostered significant growth in participants' professional and interpersonal skills. Faculty, students, and community members developed critical business acumen, improved their communication abilities, and strengthened teamwork and leadership capacities. Several participants transitioned to leadership roles within startups and research initiatives, reflecting the program's success in preparing individuals for entrepreneurial and professional endeavors. A participant even became the CEO of a local community startup incubator and now collaborates with our ecosystem.

Infrastructure Development

FAU invested in virtual platforms and upgraded facilities to support hybrid learning during the COVID-19 pandemic. These improvements enabled broader participation and ensured continuity of the program’s goals despite global challenges.

Conclusion

The FAU I-Corps Site has successfully achieved its objectives, demonstrating significant intellectual and societal impacts. By equipping participants with entrepreneurial tools and fostering a collaborative innovation ecosystem, the program has positioned southeastern Florida as a hub for STEM innovation and commercialization. Its commitment to diversity, education, and technological advancement ensures lasting benefits for the community and beyond.


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Dimitris A Pados

This report summarizes the outcomes and impacts of the project, emphasizing its intellectual merit and broader societal benefits.

Approximately      15 teams progressed to apply and were eligible for National I-Corps      training, with some advancing to SBIR/STTR grant applications.
The      project facilitated interdisciplinary learning, equipping participants      with business and entrepreneurial skills critical for translating research      to real-world applications.

The FAU I-Corps Site has profoundly impacted southeastern Floridas entrepreneurial ecosystem, driving societal and economic benefits.

Diversity      and Inclusion: Women and minority-led teams constituted over 50% of      participants, reflecting FAUs commitment to equitable access and      inclusion in entrepreneurship.

Sharkskin      Bandage: A biomimetic invention designed to reduce reinfections,      potentially saving healthcare costs and improving patient outcomes.
Spods:      Providing accessible sanitation solutions for underserved communities,      enhancing public health and hygiene.
CubeSat      Team: Developed a miniature satellite prototype, enabling advancements      in space exploration and food sustainability, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration among      engineering and science students.

Its commitment to diversity, education, and technological advancement ensures lasting benefits for the community and beyond.					Last Modified: 01/29/2025
